Requesting Audit, Tax Accrual or Tax Reconciliation
Audit, Tax Accrual or Tax Reconciliation 4.10.20
Purpose: This IRM states the policy and guidelines that examiners must use when requesting taxpayer workpapers, such as:
tigation. (
) Policy Owner: Commissioner, Large Business and International Division (LB&I) (
) Program Owner: Office of Tax Shelter Analysis (OTSA), LB&I (
) Related Resource: See the Tax Accrual Workpapers Frequently Asked Questions on IRS.gov at https://www.irs.gov/businesses/corporations/tax- accrual-workpapers-frequently-asked-questions. (

) Tax Reconciliation Workpapers Tax reconciliation workpapers are used in assembling and compiling ﬁnancial data in preparation for placement on a tax return. These workpapers typically include ﬁnal trial balances for each entity and a schedule of consolidating and adjusting entries. They include used to trace ﬁnancial information to the tax return. Any tax return preparation documents that reconcile net income per books or ﬁnancial statements to taxable income are also tax reconciliation workpapers. Tax reconciliation papers do not become tax accrual workpapers when they are used in the preparation of tax accrual workpapers or are attached to tax accrual workpa- pers. Preexisting documents that a taxpayer, the taxpayer’s accountant, or taxpayer’s independent auditor consults, refers to, or relies upon in making evaluations or decisions regarding the tax reserves or in performing an audit are not themselves considered tax accrual workpapers or audit workpapers, even though the taxpayer, the taxpayer’s accountant, or independent auditor may store such documents with the tax accrual workpapers or audit workpa- pers. (

) Tax Accrual Workpapers The term “tax accrual workpapers” refers to those audit workpapers, whether prepared by the taxpayer, the taxpayer’s accoun- tant, or the independent auditor, that relate to the tax reserve for current, deferred and potential or contingent tax liabilities, however classiﬁed or reported on audited ﬁnancial statements, and to footnotes disclosing those reserves on audited ﬁnancial statements. These workpapers reﬂect an estimate of a company’s tax liabilities and may also be referred to as the tax pool analysis, tax liability contingency analysis, tax cushion analysis, or tax contingency reserve analysis. The name given the workpapers by the the taxpayer’s accountant, or the independent auditor is not determinative.
4.10 Examination of Returns

Examination of a. Tax accrual workpapers typically include determinations and related documentation of estimates of potential or contingent tax liabilities to tax positions taken by the taxpayer on certain transactions. In there may be an audit trail and/or complete explanation of the tions. There may also be information on whether there was reliance outside legal advice; an assessment of the taxpayer’s position and potential for sustention; references to promotional materials; and comments on unwritten agreements, conﬁdentiality agreements, tion agreements, contingency fees, expectations, and other material surrounding the transactions. The workpapers may include written by the taxpayer’s employees and officers describing or the tax strategies. The scope and quality of the workpapers will vary. b. The total amount of the reserve established on a company’s general ledger for all contingent tax liabilities of the company for a speciﬁc reporting period is not considered a part of the company’s tax accrual workpapers. An examiner may ask a taxpayer about the existence the total amount of a reserve for all contingent tax liabilities as a of routine examination procedure, without a showing of unusual stances and without seeking executive approval for the request. c. A request to reveal the existence or amount of a tax reserve for any speciﬁc known or unknown transaction, however, is the same asking for a description of a portion of the contents of the tax accrual workpapers. Requests for a description of the contents of the tax workpapers are covered by the same policy of restraint as requests the actual documents that make up the tax accrual workpapers. (

) Audit Workpapers These are workpapers created by or for the auditor. They are retained by the independent auditor and may be shared the taxpayer. These workpapers include information about the procedures followed, the tests performed, the information obtained, and the reached pertinent to the independent auditor’s review of a taxpayer’s statements. Audit workpapers may include work programs, analyses, memoranda, letters of conﬁrmation and representation, abstracts of documents, and schedules or commentaries prepared or obtained by the auditor. These workpapers provide important support for the independent auditor’s opinion as to the fairness of the presentation of the ﬁnancial ments, in conformity with generally accepted auditing standards and accepted accounting principles. (

) The table below lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions: Acronym Deﬁnition CFR Code of Federal Regulations IDR Information Document Request OTSA Office of Tax Shelter Analysis P&A Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administra- tion) UTP Uncertain Tax Position

a. Tax accrual workpapers typically include determinations and related documentation of estimates of potential or contingent tax liabilities related to tax positions taken by the taxpayer on certain transactions. In addition, there may be an audit trail and/or complete explanation of the transac

tions. There may also be information on whether there was reliance on outside legal advice; an assessment of the taxpayer’s position and potential for sustention; references to promotional materials; and comments on unwritten agreements, conﬁdentiality agreements, restitu

tion agreements, contingency fees, expectations, and other material facts surrounding the transactions. The workpapers may include documents written by the taxpayer’s employees and officers describing or evaluating the tax strategies. The scope and quality of the workpapers will vary. b. The total amount of the reserve established on a company’s general ledger for all contingent tax liabilities of the company for a speciﬁc reporting period is not considered a part of the company’s tax accrual workpapers. An examiner may ask a taxpayer about the existence and the total amount of a reserve for all contingent tax liabilities as a matter of routine examination procedure, without a showing of unusual circum

stances and without seeking executive approval for the request. c. A request to reveal the existence or amount of a tax reserve established for any speciﬁc known or unknown transaction, however, is the same as asking for a description of a portion of the contents of the tax accrual workpapers. Requests for a description of the contents of the tax accrual workpapers are covered by the same policy of restraint as requests for the actual documents that make up the tax accrual workpapers.
The table below lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

) Tax reconciliation workpapers should be requested as a routine matter at the beginning of an examination. Ordinarily, tax reconciliation workpapers are for prepared and provided by the taxpayer. If these workpapers are unavailable Tax from the taxpayer, access will be sought from the taxpayer’s accountants. (

) Taxpayers may redact the following information from any copies of tax recon- ciliation workpapers relating to the preparation of Schedule UTP, Uncertain Position Statement: a. Working drafts, revisions, or comments concerning the concise descrip- tion of tax positions reported on Schedule UTP; b. The amount of any reserve related to a tax position reported on UTP; and c. Computations determining the ranking of tax positions to be reported on Schedule UTP or the designation of a tax position as a Major Tax Position. Other than requiring the disclosure of information on the Schedule UTP, the requirement to ﬁle Schedule UTP does not affect the policy of restraint. (
) The general standard for requests for audit or tax accrual workpapers is the unusual circumstances standard, see IRM
This standard applies for all requests for audit workpapers and requests for tax accrual workpapers Audit or Tax do not involve a listed transaction as deﬁned in
CFR
For the standard on requesting tax accrual workpapers involving a listed transaction, see IRM
) In unusual circumstances (as deﬁned in paragraph (

) below), the Service request audit or tax accrual workpapers. Examiners should keep in mind that the taxpayer’s records are the primary source of factual data to support the return. Audit or tax accrual workpapers should normally be sought only when such factual data cannot be obtained from the taxpayer’s records or from available third parties, and then only as a collateral source for factual data. Audit or tax accrual workpapers should be requested with discretion and not a matter of standard examining procedure. This request should generally be made ﬁrst to the taxpayer, but may be directed to the taxpayer, the taxpayer’s accountant, the independent auditor, or all three, based on the Service’s mination as to the location of the workpapers sought. The request should be limited to the portion of the workpapers that is material and relevant to the amination. Whether an item is considered to be material is based upon the examiner’s judgment and an evaluation of the facts and circumstances of the case. (

) Unusual circumstances for this purpose exist under the following conditions: a. A speciﬁc issue has been identiﬁed by the examiner for which there exists a need for additional facts; b. The examiner has sought from the taxpayer and available third parties of the facts known to them relating to the identiﬁed issue; c. The examiner has sought a supplementary analysis (not necessarily contained in the audit or tax accrual workpapers) of facts relating to the identiﬁed issue; and (

) Although the Supreme Court recognized the Service’s right to obtain tax accrual workpapers in United States v. Arthur Young & Co.,
U.S.
), the Service announced that it would continue its policy of restraint would not request tax accrual workpapers as a standard examination technique. (Announcement
IRB

, the Service modiﬁed its policy of restraint with respect to tax accrual workpapers. In general, the modiﬁed policy applies to returns ﬁled by taxpayers claiming beneﬁts from listed transactions. (Announcement

) listed transactions to include substantially similar transactions. The policy governing requests for tax accrual workpapers involving listed transactions varies according to when the tax return was ﬁled. (
) If a listed transaction was properly disclosed on the return, in the manner scribed by
CFR

, the Service will routinely request tax accrual workpapers that pertain only to the listed transaction for the year under nation. In these circumstances, the Service may also request tax accrual workpapers pertaining to the disclosed listed transaction for a year(s) not under examination, if such workpapers may be directly relevant to the Service’s audit for the year under examination, such as those described in paragraph (
) If, however, a listed transaction was not timely and properly disclosed in the manner described by
CFR

, the Service will routinely request all tax accrual workpapers for the year under examination. In these circum- stances, the Service may also request tax accrual workpapers for years not under examination, if such workpapers may be directly relevant to the Service’s audit of any known listed transactions for the year(s) under tion. (

) As a discretionary matter, all tax accrual workpapers for the year under nation will be requested if: a. The Service determines that the taxpayer claimed tax beneﬁts from multiple listed transactions that were all properly disclosed; or b. In connection with the examination of a return claiming tax beneﬁts a single listed transaction that was disclosed, there are reported irregularities with respect to the taxpayer. Note: In either of these circumstances, the Service may also request accrual workpapers pertaining to the known listed transactions or the reported ﬁnancial irregularities for years not under if such workpapers may be directly relevant to the audit for the years under examination. There may be reported ﬁnancial irregu- larities where the beneﬁt from a listed transaction, disclosed on return, does not reconcile to the related tax accrual in the ing ﬁnancial statements. (

) The term “as a discretionary matter” as used in this section of the IRM the exercise of prudence in executing policies. Wherever this term is used within this section of the IRM, the presumption is that the Service will all tax accrual workpapers. There may be rare instances in which requesting
The examiner has performed a reconciliation of the taxpayer’s Schedule M-1 or M-3 as it pertains to the identiﬁed issue.

) The term “as a discretionary matter” as used in this section of the IRM denotes the exercise of prudence in executing policies. Wherever this term is used within this section of the IRM, the presumption is that the Service will request all tax accrual workpapers. There may be rare instances in which requesting
Audit, Tax Accrual or Tax Reconciliation 4.10.20
page 5
all workpapers might not be appropriate. For example, if the taxpayer fully concedes the issues, including penalties, pertaining to all listed transactions and the parties have executed a Form
, Closing Agreement on Final mination Covering Speciﬁc Matters, with respect to the issues conceded by taxpayer, then it may be appropriate not to seek all of the tax accrual pers. (

) If there is an exceptional situation where the examiner believes it is not priate to pursue all of the tax accrual workpapers, approval not to request all the workpapers would be required. For LB&I cases, the approval by the Director, Field Operations, LB&I is required. For SB/SE cases, approval by Area Compliance Director, with the concurrence of the Director of Policy, SB/SE is required. For TE/GE cases, approval by the Director, EO aminations; the Director, EP Examinations; or the Director, Government Entities is required. (
) If a transaction becomes a listed transaction, within the deﬁnition in
CFR

, subsequent to the ﬁling of a tax return, the tax accrual workpapers will be requested, so long as at the time of the request the transaction is a listed transaction. Some listing notices contain effective dates which should also be considered in determining whether a transaction is listed. The examiner should work with Field Counsel to make these determinations. (

) Upon determining that a request for audit and/or tax accrual workpapers should be made, the examiner will prepare an Information Document (IDR) for the workpapers. The examiner should work with Field Counsel in preparing the IDR. In all cases potentially involving requests and for Audit and/or Tax Accrual Workpapers, Field Counsel will coordinate the case with Headquarters. Upon determining that a request for audit and/or tax accrual workpapers should be made, the examiner will prepare an Information Document Request (IDR) for the workpapers. The examiner should work with Field Counsel in preparing the IDR. In all cases potentially involving requests and summonses for Audit and/or Tax Accrual Workpapers, Field Counsel will coordinate the case with Headquarters. Procedures for coordinating the review of IDRs are outlined in IRM 4.10.20.4.(3). Procedures for coordinating the review of summonses are outlined in IRM 4.10.20.4.1.1, and IRM 4.10.20.4.1.2. Coordi- nation with Counsel will be treated as a high priority matter by Counsel so as not to delay the examination.

Any IDR for audit or tax accrual workpapers should contain a request that, in the event a taxpayer or third party does not produce a document requested by the IDR, the taxpayer or third party should provide the examiner with a de- scription of the document being withheld, including the number of pages contained in the document, and the speciﬁc reason why the document is not being provided in response to the IDR. If a document is not produced based on a claim of privilege, the taxpayer or third party should provide the examiner with a detailed privilege log. However, if the taxpayer or a third party to whom

Examination of an IDR is issued fails to provide (or unreasonably delays providing) the requested descriptions of documents being withheld and/or the requested detailed privilege log for any privilege being claimed, the examiner should promptly issue an appropriate summons, as described in IRM
, Issuance of Summonses, requesting all withheld workpapers. (

) Before an IDR for these workpapers is issued, review or approval must occur. a. For requests under LB&I’s unusual circumstances standard, approval must be obtained from the Director, Field Operations, LB&I. For SB/SE cases, approval must be obtained from the Area Compliance Director, with the concurrence of the Director of Compliance Policy, SB/SE. For TE/GE cases, approval must be obtained from the Director, EO tions; the Director, EP Examinations; or the Director, Government b. For requests involving listed transactions, the team manager in LB&I cases, or group manager in SB/SE and TE/GE cases, must review any IDR requesting tax accrual workpapers. (
) The examiner should follow IRM Exhibit
, Requirements for Issuing IDRs, and IRM Exhibit
, IDR Enforcement Process. (
) The standards and procedures for issuing a summons will differ depending upon whether the request for workpapers was made under the unusual stances standard (see IRM
) or involved a listed transaction (see IRM

) If it is necessary to issue a summons to secure audit or tax accrual workpa- pers under the unusual circumstances standard, the examiner should ensure or that the burden of compliance with the summons will not be unreasonable. summons should provide a speciﬁc and clear description of the records demanded so that the summoned party can reasonably be expected to the exact records sought. The summons must also identify the particular taxpayer for which the documents are sought, the period covered, and the nature of the documents. Unless the examiner determines that all of the papers are material and relevant, the summons should identify and request only those documents relating to the speciﬁc matters under consideration. Finally, the summons should specify whether it seeks audit or tax accrual workpapers, or both. (

) In LB&I cases, prior approval for the issuance of summonses for audit or tax accrual workpapers must be obtained from the Director, Field Operations, LB&I. In SB/SE cases, prior approval for the issuance of such summonses must be obtained from the Area Compliance Director, with the concurrence of the Director of Compliance Policy, SB/SE. In TE/GE cases, approval for such requests must be obtained from the Director, EO Examinations; the Director, EP Examinations; or the Director, Government Entities. (

) Prior to issuance, a summons for audit or tax accrual workpapers accompa- nied by a statement of applicable facts and circumstances will be submitted Field Counsel for review and comment. Pre-issuance approval is required P&A (and possibly from the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations)) under CC Notice
and CCDM

Division Counsel approval is required before Field Counsel may submit any formal request for assistance to P&A Technical Services Support Assignments, or before submitting any summons enforcement referral letter to P&A for review and approval. Field counsel will Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Audit, Tax Accrual or Tax Reconciliation 4.10.20

coordinate with a Special Counsel in Headquarters, who will further coordinate the approval of the Division Counsel. Coordination with Counsel will be treated as a high priority matter by Counsel so as not to delay the examination. National Office Counsel review of the summons will, in general, be completed no later than fourteen days after coordination with P&A occurs. The approval process is as follows:

National Office Counsel review of the summons will, in general, be no later than fourteen days after coordination with P&A occurs. The approval process is as follows: a. Field Counsel will provide the Special Counsel with a detailed dum describing why the tax accrual workpapers are necessary to Examination’s development of the case and how the particular case meets the unusual circumstances exception. b. If Division Counsel concurs with Field Counsel’s request, Division Counsel will forward a memorandum to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for P&A’s consideration and approval. (

) Field Counsel will review the summons to ensure that the summons is priately drafted and meets all legal requirements. The summons should be directed to the taxpayer, the taxpayer’s accountant, the independent auditor, all three, based on a determination as to the location of the workpapers. (
) The examiner must prepare a summons for workpapers that are not in response to an IDR. (

) When the examiner prepares a summons for the workpapers, a statement of the facts and circumstances should also be prepared. The records sought must be described with reasonable certainty. The requirement of reasonable certainty will be satisﬁed if the description of the records is speciﬁc and clear and the summoned party can reasonably be expected to identify the exact records sought. The summons must include the identiﬁcation of the particular taxpayer for which the documents are sought, the period the documents and the nature of the documents. (

) For LB&I cases, pre-issuance review of summonses for tax accrual workpa- pers must be obtained from the Director, Field Operations, LB&I. For SB/SE cases, pre-issuance review of summonses must be obtained from the Area Compliance Director, with the concurrence of the Director of Compliance Policy, SB/SE. For TE/GE cases, pre-issuance review of summonses must obtained from the Director, EO Examinations; the Director, EP Examinations; or the Director, Government Entities. (
) The examiner will work with Field Counsel to prepare the summons. Pre- issuance approval is required from P&A (and possibly the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations)) under CC Notice
and CCDM

Division Counsel approval is required before Field Counsel may submit any formal request for assistance to P&A via Technical Services Support Assign- ments, or before submitting any summons enforcement referral letter to P&A for review and approval. Field Counsel will coordinate with a Special Counsel in Headquarters, who will further coordinate the approval of the Division Counsel review of the summons through the appropriate Division Counsel P&A. Coordination with Counsel will be treated as a high priority matter by Counsel so as not to delay the examination. Any National Office Counsel review of the summons will, in general, be completed no later than seven after coordination with P&A occurs.

a. Field Counsel will provide the Special Counsel with a detailed dum describing why the tax accrual workpapers are necessary to Examination’s development of the case and how the particular case meets the unusual circumstances exception. b. If Division Counsel concurs with Field Counsel’s request, Division Counsel will forward a memorandum to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for P&A’s consideration and approval.
(12-08-2020) Summonses for Tax Accrual Workpapers Involving Listed Transactions

The examiner will work with Field Counsel to prepare the summons. Pre- issuance approval is required from P&A (and possibly the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations)) under CC Notice 2016-009 and CCDM 34.6.3.6.1. Division Counsel approval is required before Field Counsel may submit any formal request for assistance to P&A via Technical Services Support Assign- ments, or before submitting any summons enforcement referral letter to P&A for review and approval. Field Counsel will coordinate with a Special Counsel in Headquarters, who will further coordinate the approval of the Division Counsel review of the summons through the appropriate Division Counsel P&A. Coordination with Counsel will be treated as a high priority matter by Counsel so as not to delay the examination. Any National Office Counsel review of the summons will, in general, be completed no later than seven

a. Field Counsel will provide the Special Counsel with a detailed dum describing why the tax accrual workpapers are necessary to Examination’s development of the case and how the particular case within the listed transaction exception to the Service’s policy of b. If Division Counsel concurs with Field Counsel’s request, Division Counsel will forward a memorandum to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for P&A’s consideration and approval. (

) Field Counsel will review the summons to ensure it is appropriately drafted meets all legal requirements. The summons should be directed to the the taxpayer’s accountant, the independent auditor, or all three, based on a determination as to the location of the workpapers. (

) If the summoned party does not comply with the summons, the examiner refer the matter to Counsel for enforcement of the summons, following a sultation with the Director, Field Operations, LB&I, for LB&I cases; or, for SB/SE cases, following a consultation with the Area Compliance Director, the concurrence of the Director of Compliance Policy, SB/SE; or for TE/GE cases, following consultation with the Director, EO Examinations; the EP Examinations; or the Director, Government Entities. a. For summonses involving listed transactions and requests for tax workpapers, the summons enforcement letter will be approved by the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations) after coordination with, and pre- review by, the responsible Division Counsel and P&A. b. For all other summonses seeking tax accrual or other audit the summons enforcement letter must be coordinated with, and pre- reviewed by, the responsible Division Counsel and P&A.
Field Counsel will provide the Special Counsel with a detailed memoran

dum describing why the tax accrual workpapers are necessary to Examination’s development of the case and how the particular case falls within the listed transaction exception to the Service’s policy of restraint. If Division Counsel concurs with Field Counsel’s request, Division Counsel will forward a memorandum to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for P&A’s consideration and approval.
